Decentralized Federated Learning with Asynchronous Parameter Sharing for Large-scale IoT Networks

Haihui Xie, Minghua Xia, , Peiran Wu, ,

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) enables wireless terminals to collaboratively learn a shared parameter model while keeping all the training data on devices per se. Parameter sharing consists of synchronous and asynchronous ways: the former transmits parameters as blocks or frames and waits until all transmissions finish, whereas the latter provides messages about the status of pending and failed parameter transmission requests. Whatever synchronous or asynchronous parameter sharing is applied, the learning model shall adapt to distinct network architectures as an improper learning model will deteriorate learning performance and, even worse, lead to model divergence for the asynchronous transmission in resource-limited large-scale Internet-of-Things (IoT) networks. This paper proposes a decentralized learning model and develops an asynchronous parameter-sharing algorithm for resource-limited distributed IoT networks. This decentralized learning model approaches a convex function as the number of nodes increases, and its learning process converges to a global stationary point with a higher probability than the centralized FL model. Moreover, by jointly accounting for the convergence bound of federated learning and the transmission delay of wireless communications, we develop a node scheduling and bandwidth allocation algorithm to minimize the transmission delay. Extensive simulation results corroborate the effectiveness of the distributed algorithm in terms of fast learning model convergence and low transmission delay.

Index Terms:
Asynchronous communications, distributed algorithm, federated learning, large-scale IoT networks, transmission delay.

I Introduction

The phenomenal development of wireless networking technologies yields a volume of various sensory data, such as traffic information and industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) data. As massive amounts of data are typically required to train a machine learning (ML) model, e.g., convolutional neural networks (CNN), traditional ML algorithms must gather training data from edge devices. Moreover, to realize data sharing, it is essential to transmit a large dataset to an edge server for training ML models. However, limited communication resources for data transmission and conveying large volumes of data by edge devices may substantially burden wireless communications, regardless of privacy constraints. Therefore, edge learning has been proposed to train local models over distributed edge nodes, allowing edge nodes to contribute to the learning procedure for consensus without any raw data exchange. More specifically, federated learning (FL) is, in essence, collaborative edge learning, which deploys large data over multiple edge nodes and then collaborates in training local models without sharing their possibly private data. Moreover, various network architectures regarding computational models and communication mechanisms exist to realize efficient computation and reliable communications.

I-A Related Works and Motivation

From the perceptive of computational models, there are two main categories: centralized and decentralized, as shown in Fig. 1. Specifically, the federated averaging model is a typical centralized model with a central server to orchestrate a training process, as shown in Fig. 1a. After receiving local models from the participating nodes, the central server is responsible for parameter aggregation [1]. However, the centralized model requires massive communications between the edge server and nodes, which is usually not feasible. To deal with this infeasibility, decentralized FL models have recently emerged to significantly reduce the transmission delay because all nodes only communicate with their neighbors, as shown in Fig. 1b. For example, the work [2] optimizes the linking weights of peer-to-peer communications to realize efficient communication in the decentralized scheme. The work [3] exploits the cross gradients and develops a novel decentralized learning algorithm, which reduces the communication cost and maintains a satisfactory learning performance for various data distributions.

From the perceptive of communication mechanisms, there are synchronous transmission [4, 5] and asynchronous transmission [6, 7]. For a synchronous scheme, the server cannot aggregate local models until participating nodes finish uploading their local models. Specifically, the works [4, 5] adopt synchronous FL architectures to balance resource budget and learning accuracy adaptively. By using dynamic aggregation frequency [4] or node scheduling [5], these architectures could address resource-limited problems in the learning process. Nevertheless, while multiple nodes have extensive data for model training or suffer from high transmission delays, synchronous schemes must wait for uploading models. Moreover, the waiting time leads to idling and wastage of computational resources. To address these issues, asynchronous schemes are proposed. The works [6, 7] design asynchronous FL systems to reduce transmission delay. However, these asynchronous schemes may yield objective inconsistency, i.e., the learning model may be far from the desired one. The inconsistency between local and global models potentially deteriorates convergence and, even worse, leads to model divergence as the number of iterations increases. In addition, asynchronous schemes often lack theoretical identifications to guarantee convergence, particularly for non-convex FL models.

From the perspective of wireless resource allocation, many works have been on designing communication-efficient FL algorithms that enable edge nodes to efficiently train and transmit model parameters and significantly improve learning performance and convergence rate. For instance, the works [8, 9] focus on joint scheduling and bandwidth allocation algorithm designs while guaranteeing learning performance. To characterize the theoretical relations between the number of communication rounds and learning performance, the work [10] made a tradeoff for joint optimization, including communication latencies and energy consumption. Hence, realizing efficient communication and minimizing transmission delay is essential for distributed algorithms in large-scale IoT networks.

This paper develops a decentralized FL model with asynchronous parameter sharing to address the abovementioned issues. In particular, the proposed model has multi-branch architectures and allows various learning parameters at each node, forming a sum of multi-branch non-convex functions. By recalling the Shapley-Folkman lemma [11], a sum of multi-branch non-convex functions can approach a convex function when the number of branches becomes large. Thus, the decentralized FL model is less non-convex, and its learning process converges to a global stationary point with a higher probability than the centralized FL model. In addition, when the dataset is uniformly deployed over each node, and the size of the dataset becomes large, the learning performance and convergence rate of training algorithms improve with the number of distributed nodes increases.111In principle, the assumption requires that the data distribution at each node is identical to the distribution of the total dataset [12], which is unfortunately hard to satisfy in real-world applications. To address this issue, the cross-gradient aggregation (CGA) algorithm is widely used in simulation experiments to approach the distribution of the total dataset [3]. On the one hand, the asynchronous parameter-sharing mechanism makes the learning and parameter transmission occur in parallel. Thus, a high learning efficiency can be obtained compared with a synchronous architecture. On the other hand, designing a decentralized FL model at the distributed nodes requires an efficient communication network that balances learning performance maximization and transmission delay minimization. In this regard, the asynchronous parameter-sharing method is adopted among distributed nodes. Accordingly, we derive a convergence bound incorporating transmission delay and learning performance. In light of the convergence bound and aggregated duration, we also develop algorithms regarding node scheduling and bandwidth allocation to minimize the transmission delay while maximizing the learning performance. In brevity, Table I compares the state-of-the-art and proposed schemes.

I-B Summary of Main Results

This paper starts to develop a decentralized FL model with non-convex loss functions. Then, we characterize the duality gap of the decentralized FL model by using the seminal Shapley-Folkman lemma. Next, we design a distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing and derive its convergence bound, where the transmission delay is associated with the convergence bound. At last, we design a node scheduling and bandwidth allocation algorithm to minimize the transmission delay. In brief, the major contributions of the paper are summarized as follows:

  • 1)

    A normalized duality gap is analytically attained to measure the degree of non-convexity for the decentralized FL model. This duality gap is essential to obtain a convex relaxation on loss functions, reducing the influence of non-convexity and making convergence faster.

  • 2)

    A distributed algorithm is developed to learn our decentralized model, including a gradient descent algorithm and asynchronous parameter-sharing principles. Specifically, asynchronous parameter sharing mitigates the influence of stochastic transmission delays.

  • 3)

    The transmission delay is minimized to enhance the convergence rate via efficient node scheduling and bandwidth allocation. By the convergence bound and the transmission delay, minimizing the transmission delay improves learning performance.

I-C Organization

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II formulates the decentralized learning problem. Section III derives a normalized duality gap between the primal and dual problems. Section IV develops a distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing and derives its convergence bound. Section V establishes the relationship between the transmission delay and convergence bound and allocates radio resources to minimize the transmission delay effectively. Section VI presents and discusses the experimental results; finally, Section VII concludes the paper.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

In this section, we develop a decentralized FL model with an asynchronous parameter-sharing transmission. As shown in Fig. 2, the decentralized FL model involves I𝐼I distributed nodes, local datasets {𝒟1,𝒟2,⋯,𝒟I}subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2⋯subscript𝒟𝐼\left\{\mathcal{D}_{1},\,\mathcal{D}_{2},\,\cdots,\,\mathcal{D}_{I}\right\}, local parameters {𝒘1,𝒘2,⋯,𝒘I}subscript𝒘1subscript𝒘2⋯subscript𝒘𝐼\left\{\bm{w}_{1},\,\bm{w}_{2},\,\cdots,\,\bm{w}_{I}\right\}, local aggregated parameters {𝒗1,𝒗2,⋯,𝒗I}subscript𝒗1subscript𝒗2⋯subscript𝒗𝐼\left\{\bm{v}_{1},\,\bm{v}_{2},\,\cdots,\,\bm{v}_{I}\right\}, and local loss functions {F1​(𝒗1),F2​(𝒗2),⋯,FI​(𝒗I)}subscript𝐹1subscript𝒗1subscript𝐹2subscript𝒗2⋯subscript𝐹𝐼subscript𝒗𝐼\left\{F_{1}(\bm{v}_{1}),\,F_{2}(\bm{v}_{2}),\,\cdots,\,F_{I}(\bm{v}_{I})\right\}, where 𝒗i,∀i∈ℐsubscript𝒗𝑖for-all𝑖ℐ\bm{v}_{i},\,\forall i\in\mathcal{I} denotes a locally aggregated parameter at node i𝑖i. For model learning, node i𝑖i transmits 𝒘i​(τj,i​(t))subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}\left(\tau_{j,\,i}(t)\right) to node j𝑗j at the (τj,i​(t))thsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡th\left(\tau_{j,\,i}(t)\right)^{\rm th} iteration, and then node j𝑗j learns an independent loss function Fj​(𝒗j)subscript𝐹𝑗subscript𝒗𝑗F_{j}(\bm{v}_{j}) while receiving 𝒘i​(τj,i​(t))subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}\left(\tau_{j,\,i}(t)\right) at the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\rm th} iteration, where τj,i​(t)subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡\tau_{j,\,i}(t) is a transmission iteration before the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\rm th} iteration. Clearly, there exists a transmission period t−τj,i​(t)𝑡subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡t-\tau_{j,\,i}(t) during parameter transmission between nodes i𝑖i and j𝑗j. Meanwhile, node i𝑖i can obtain an aggregated parameter 𝒗i​(t)subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡\bm{v}_{i}(t) while receiving all 𝒘j​(τi,j​(t))subscript𝒘𝑗subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡\bm{w}_{j}(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)) from other nodes j∈ℐ∖i𝑗ℐ𝑖j\in\mathcal{I}\setminus i. Moreover, Fig. 2 also shows that the number of nodes involved in the decentralized learning model is associated with the number of learning parameters 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{i}, and hence the proposed model with the summation function involves each independent 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{i}. From the perspective of non-convex geometric analysis, the sum of multiple non-convex functions approaches a convex function [11, 12]. Therefore, as reproduced below, the decentralized model becomes less non-convex than the centralized FL model by recalling the Shapley-Folkman lemma.

Lemma 1 (The Shapley-Folkman lemma[11]).

Moreover, 𝒘i|shsubscript𝒘conditional𝑖sh\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}} is updated from other nodes and then restricts the amount of local deviation relative to the desired model, defined as

𝒘i|sh​(t)≜11−αi​∑j∈ℐ∖iαj​𝒘j​(τi,j​(t)).≜subscript𝒘conditional𝑖sh𝑡11subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑗ℐ𝑖subscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝒘𝑗subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}}(t)\triangleq\dfrac{1}{1-\alpha_{i}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{I}\setminus i}\alpha_{j}\bm{w}_{j}\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right). (1)

Moreover, (3b) denotes a soft constraint in which the corresponding hard constraint is replaced by regularization. This replacement can control the complexity of a neural network model to avoid over-fitting and restrict the divergence of parameters arising due to heterogeneity in the data distribution [19].

Remark 1.

The proposed decentralized model can attain a higher learning efficiency and less non-convex FL model than the centralized one since the former makes the learning and data exchange parallel. Also, the latter with cell-interior scheduling leads to data deficiency since the resultant model training fails to exploit data at cell-edge devices[20]. To address this issue, the proposed method uses the shared parameter with the desired transmission delay and then improves the data quantity.

So far, we have formulated a decentralized FL problem. By recalling the seminal Shapley-Folkman lemma, we can infer that the sum result in the objective function of 𝒫​1𝒫1\mathcal{P}1 becomes more and more convex as the number of nodes (i.e., I𝐼I) increases. Therefore, designing algorithms to solve 𝒫​1𝒫1\mathcal{P}1 efficiently improves the FL convergence rate.

III Duality Gap of The Decentralized FL Model

Although we have formulated a multi-branch problem, building a direct relationship between the node distribution and loss function takes time and effort. To address this issue, this section derives a normalized duality gap between the decentralized FL problem and its dual one to measure the degree of non-convexity. To start with, the dual problem of 𝒫​1𝒫1\mathcal{P}1 is given by

where 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}} denotes an optimal variable of F~i​(𝒘~)subscript~𝐹𝑖~𝒘\tilde{F}_{i}(\tilde{\bm{w}}), Ni≥2subscript𝑁𝑖2N_{i}\geq 2 is an arbitrary integer which makes F~i​(𝒘~)subscript~𝐹𝑖~𝒘\tilde{F}_{i}(\tilde{\bm{w}}) significant, and 𝒙jsubscript𝒙𝑗\bm{x}_{j} denotes a sampling variable of the Euclidean space. Also, we use 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}} again to rewrite the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\rm th} sub-function in 𝒫​1𝒫1\mathcal{P}1 as

F^i​(𝒘~)=inf𝒘i∈𝒲i{Fi​((1−αi)​𝒘i|sh+αi​𝒘i)|r​(𝒘i)≤r​(𝒘~)}.subscript^𝐹𝑖~𝒘subscriptinfimumsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝒲𝑖conditional-setsubscript𝐹𝑖1subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝒘conditional𝑖shsubscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖𝑟subscript𝒘𝑖𝑟~𝒘\small\hat{F}_{i}(\tilde{\bm{w}})=\inf_{\bm{w}_{i}\in\mathcal{W}_{i}}\left\{F_{i}\left((1-\alpha_{i})\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}}+\alpha_{i}\bm{w}_{i}\right)\left|r(\bm{w}_{i})\leq r(\tilde{\bm{w}})\right.\right\}. (6)

Here, we choose an appropriate Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i} such that r​(𝒘~)≥Ki,i∈ℐformulae-sequence𝑟~𝒘subscript𝐾𝑖𝑖ℐr(\tilde{\bm{w}})\geq K_{i},\,i\in\mathcal{I}. Combining (5) with (6), our conclusion is formalized in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Let the maximal divergence of all models be Δworst≜maxi∈ℐ⁡Δi≜subscriptΔworstsubscript𝑖ℐsubscriptΔ𝑖\Delta_{\rm worst}\triangleq\max_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\Delta_{i}, where Δi≜sup𝐰~∈𝒲i{F^i​(𝐰~)−F~i​(𝐰~)}≥0≜subscriptΔ𝑖subscriptsupremum~𝐰subscript𝒲𝑖subscript^𝐹𝑖~𝐰subscript~𝐹𝑖~𝐰0\Delta_{i}\triangleq\sup_{\tilde{\bm{w}}\in\mathcal{W}_{i}}\left\{\hat{F}_{i}(\tilde{\bm{w}})-\tilde{F}_{i}(\tilde{\bm{w}})\right\}\geq 0 denotes the divergence between the function value of F^isubscript^𝐹𝑖\hat{F}_{i} and its convex relaxation F~isubscript~𝐹𝑖\tilde{F}_{i}, the normalized duality gap can be bounded by

0≤inf(𝒫​1)−sup(𝒫​2)Δworst≤2​αmax,0infimum𝒫1supremum𝒫2subscriptΔworst2subscript𝛼0\leq\dfrac{\inf(\mathcal{P}1)-\sup(\mathcal{P}2)}{\Delta_{\rm worst}}\leq 2\alpha_{\max}, (7)

where αmax≜maxi=1,2,⋯,I⁡αi≜subscript𝛼subscript𝑖12⋯𝐼subscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{\max}\triangleq\max_{i=1,2,\cdots,I}\alpha_{i}.

Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

In Theorem 1, although the divergence ΔisubscriptΔ𝑖\Delta_{i} changes from node to node, the maximal divergence ΔworstsubscriptΔworst\Delta_{\rm worst} among all nodes remains almost the same in case the number I𝐼I of nodes is large enough. Accordingly, the normalized duality gap (inf(𝒫​1)−sup(𝒫​2))/Δworstinfimum𝒫1supremum𝒫2subscriptΔworst\left(\inf(\mathcal{P}1)-\sup(\mathcal{P}2)\right)/\Delta_{\rm worst} in (7) measures the degree of non-convexity for the objective function. When differences in the data distribution among all distributed nodes turn larger, i.e., αmax→1→subscript𝛼1\alpha_{\max}\rightarrow 1, the upper bound of (7) becomes looser, and the proposed model degenerates into a centralized FL model. In contrast, when a large dataset has a uniform distribution over each node, i.e., α1=⋯=αI=αmax→1/Isubscript𝛼1⋯subscript𝛼𝐼subscript𝛼→1𝐼\alpha_{1}=\cdots=\alpha_{I}=\alpha_{\max}\rightarrow 1/I, the upper bound of (7) takes the minimum value, i.e., 2/I2𝐼2/I. Clearly, the normalized duality gap decreases linearly with I𝐼I. In other words, 𝒫​1𝒫1\mathcal{P}1 becomes more and more convex as I𝐼I increases. As a result, the solution of 𝒫​1𝒫1\mathcal{P}1 approaches that of 𝒫​2𝒫2\mathcal{P}2 as I→+∞→𝐼I\rightarrow+\infty.

IV Algorithm Design and Convergence Analysis

By using the duality gap, we can now control the non-convexity of our decentralized FL model by adjusting the number of nodes. The learning process can also converge to a global solution with a high probability. Next, we develop a distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing, followed by an analytical upper bound to guarantee convergence.

IV-A Algorithm Design

Based on the decentralized FL model shown in Fig. 2, we now design a distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing for learning relative parameters. The following assumptions are prerequisites for convergence.

Assumption 1 (pp. 483-484 of [21]).

Assume that the number of transmission delays ΓΓ\Gamma, i.e., how usually all scheduled nodes participate in an asynchronous aggregation, is a positive integer, then the transmission iteration τi,j​(t)subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡\tau_{i,\,j}(t) satisfies

max⁡{t−Γ, 0}<τi,j​(t)≤t,∀i≠j, and ​τi,i​(t)=t.formulae-sequence𝑡Γ 0subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡𝑡formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝑗 and subscript𝜏𝑖𝑖𝑡𝑡\max\{t-\Gamma,\,0\}<\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\leq t,\,\forall i\neq j,\text{ and }\tau_{i,\,i}(t)=t. (8)

In light of Assumption 1, it is evident that each variable 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{i} and sharing parameter 𝒘i|shsubscript𝒘conditional𝑖sh\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}} at node i𝑖i can be updated timely if ΓΓ\Gamma is bounded. However, 𝒘i|shsubscript𝒘conditional𝑖sh\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}} cannot be updated in parallel as it requires information from other nodes. Therefore, we replace the gradient descent algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing, yielding

𝒗i​(t)subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\bm{v}_{i}(t) =αi​𝒘i​(t)+(1−αi)​𝒘i|sh​(t)absentsubscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝒘conditional𝑖sh𝑡\displaystyle{}=\alpha_{i}\bm{w}_{i}(t)+(1-\alpha_{i})\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}}(t)
=∑j∈ℐαj​𝒘j​(τi,j​(t)),absentsubscript𝑗ℐsubscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝒘𝑗subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡\displaystyle{}=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{I}}\alpha_{j}\bm{w}_{j}\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right), (9)

where 𝒗i​(t)subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡\bm{v}_{i}(t), serving as an aggregated parameter, is a linear function of variables 𝒘j​(τi,j​(t))subscript𝒘𝑗subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡\bm{w}_{j}\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right), ∀j∈ℐfor-all𝑗ℐ\forall j\in\mathcal{I}. Also, 𝒘i|shsubscript𝒘conditional𝑖sh\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}} in (9) reflects information interactions among nodes and ensures that the preliminary model can be initialized properly by drawing knowledge from multiple local data distributions.

Now, we apply gradient descent algorithms to learn our FL model. At first, 𝒘i​(t)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}(t) can be updated by

𝒘i​(t+1)=[𝒘i​(t)−η​∇iFi​(𝒗i​(t))]+,subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡𝜂subscript∇𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}(t+1)=\left[\bm{w}_{i}(t)-\eta\nabla_{i}F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t))\right]^{+}, (10)

where ∇iFisubscript∇𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖\nabla_{i}F_{i} denotes the derivative of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} with respect to the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\rm th} parameter 𝒘i​(t)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}(t), i.e., ∇𝒘iFisubscript∇subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖\nabla_{\bm{w}_{i}}F_{i}. Clearly, (10) is a gradient projection algorithm[21, p. 213], which generalizes the conventional gradient decent method to the case with complex constraints. Incidentally, the mapping [⋅]+superscriptdelimited-[]⋅\left[\cdot\right]^{+}, i.e., orthogonal projection of 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{i}, can be defined as

[𝒘i]+≜argmin𝒚​‖𝒚−𝒘i‖2,∀𝒚∈𝒳i,formulae-sequence≜superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝒘𝑖𝒚argminsubscriptnorm𝒚subscript𝒘𝑖2for-all𝒚subscript𝒳𝑖\left[\bm{w}_{i}\right]^{+}\triangleq\underset{\bm{y}}{{\rm argmin}}\,\|\bm{y}-\bm{w}_{i}\|_{2},\,\forall\bm{y}\in\mathcal{X}_{i}, (11)

where 𝒳i≜{𝒚|r​(𝒚)≤Ki,∀𝒚∈𝒲i}≜subscript𝒳𝑖conditional-set𝒚formulae-sequence𝑟𝒚subscript𝐾𝑖for-all𝒚subscript𝒲𝑖\mathcal{X}_{i}\triangleq\left\{\bm{y}\left|r(\bm{y})\leq K_{i},\right.\forall\bm{y}\in\mathcal{W}_{i}\right\}. To update the mapping [⋅]+superscriptdelimited-[]⋅[\cdot]^{+}, the iterative shrinkage-thresholding algorithm with ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm constraint, the weight decay with ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm constraint or other regularized solvers can be exploited [18, 22]. Accordingly, a descent gradient of the distributed algorithm can be computed and given by

𝒔i​(t)subscript𝒔𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\bm{s}_{i}(t) ≜1η​(𝒘i​(t+1)−𝒘i​(t))≜absent1𝜂subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\triangleq\dfrac{1}{\eta}\left(\bm{w}_{i}(t+1)-\bm{w}_{i}(t)\right)
=1η​([𝒘i​(t)−η​∇iFi​(𝒗i​(t))]+−𝒘i​(t)),absent1𝜂superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡𝜂subscript∇𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\displaystyle=\dfrac{1}{\eta}\left(\left[\bm{w}_{i}(t)-\eta\nabla_{i}F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t))\right]^{+}-\bm{w}_{i}(t)\right), (12)

Thus, the local parameter given by (10) can be rewritten as

𝒘i​(t+1)=𝒘i​(t)+η​𝒔i​(t).subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡𝜂subscript𝒔𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}(t+1)=\bm{w}_{i}(t)+\eta\bm{s}_{i}(t). (13)

For illustrative purposes, Fig. 3 shows the schematic diagram for iterative learning processes, where different colored disks denote different learning iterations. By unfolding the time-series data, Fig. 3 also illustrates the network topology with transmission delays. In particular, parameter reception and transmission are two main processes. In the period of the parameter reception, node i𝑖i starts receiving the parameters from the other nodes at the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\rm th} iteration. Specifically, node j𝑗j transmits 𝒘j​(τi,j​(t))subscript𝒘𝑗subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡\bm{w}_{j}\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right) to node i𝑖i at the (τi,j​(t))thsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡th\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right)^{\rm th} iteration, where we take Γi,j≜t−τi,j​(t)≜subscriptΓ𝑖𝑗𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡\Gamma_{i,\,j}\triangleq t-\tau_{i,\,j}(t) as a communication duration and the parameter 𝒘j​(τi,j​(t))subscript𝒘𝑗subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡\bm{w}_{j}\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right) rather than the up-to-date 𝒘j​(t)subscript𝒘𝑗𝑡\bm{w}_{j}(t) is used at the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\rm th} iteration. After receiving all parameters of the set ℐ∖iℐ𝑖\mathcal{I}\setminus i, node i𝑖i performs the iteration (13). On the other hand, in the period of the parameter transmission, node i𝑖i transmits the corresponding parameter 𝒘i​(t+1)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\bm{w}_{i}(t+1) to nodes in the set ℐ∖iℐ𝑖\mathcal{I}\setminus i, where we take Γj,isubscriptΓ𝑗𝑖\Gamma_{j,\,i} as a communication duration between node i𝑖i and node j𝑗j.

IV-B Convergence Analysis

Now, we characterize the convergence for the distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing. Compared with traditional convergence analysis, it is hard to prove the convergence of our proposed algorithm due to shared and local learning parameters. To address this issue, this paper designs a new loss function that mitigates the influence of shared parameters and establishes the convergence relationship. First, we define this loss function as

F¯​(𝒘)≜∑i=1Iαi​Fi​(𝒘)=∑i=1Iαi​Fi​(∑i=1Iαi​𝒘i),≜¯𝐹𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖\bar{F}\left(\bm{w}\right)\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}F_{i}\left(\bm{w}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}F_{i}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}\bm{w}_{i}\right), (14)

where 𝒘​(t)≜∑i=1Iαi​𝒘i​(t)≜𝒘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}(t)\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}\bm{w}_{i}(t) stands for the last aggregated parameter, unlike 𝒗i​(t)subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡\bm{v}_{i}(t) shown in (9). Since the objective function in (3a) is indeterminate due to the stochastic transmission delays, (14) rather than (3a) is applied in the following convergence analysis. Then, it is sufficient to require that each variable is updated in a gradient descent direction. Accordingly, the following assumptions are introduced for the convergence analysis.

Assumption 2 (pp. 527-528 of [21]).

The objective loss and descent gradient satisfy the following conditions:

  • (a)

    There holds Fi​(𝒘)≥0,∀i∈ℐformulae-sequencesubscript𝐹𝑖𝒘0for-all𝑖ℐF_{i}(\bm{w})\geq 0,\,\forall i\in\mathcal{I}.

  • (b)

    Any function ∇Fi∇subscript𝐹𝑖\nabla F_{i} is continuously differentiable and there exists a constant L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} such that

    ‖∇Fi​(𝒙)−∇Fi​(𝒚)‖2≤L1​‖𝒙−𝒚‖2,subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒚2subscript𝐿1subscriptnorm𝒙𝒚2\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{y})\|_{2}\leq L_{1}\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|_{2},

    where ∇Fi​(𝒙)∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}) (resp., ∇Fi(𝒚\nabla F_{i}(\bm{y})) represents the derivative with respect to the aggregated variable 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} (resp., 𝒚𝒚\bm{y}).

  • (c)

    For all i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, we have

    𝒔iT​(t)​∇iFi​(𝒗i​(t))≤0.superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑇𝑡subscript∇𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡0\bm{s}_{i}^{T}(t)\nabla_{i}F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t))\leq 0.
  • (d)

    There are positive constants L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} and L3subscript𝐿3L_{3}, such that

    L2​‖∇iFi​(𝒗i​(t))‖2≤‖𝒔i​(t)‖2≤L3​‖∇iFi​(𝒗i​(t))‖2.subscript𝐿2subscriptnormsubscript∇𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡2subscriptnormsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑡2subscript𝐿3subscriptnormsubscript∇𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡2L_{2}\left\|\nabla_{i}F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t))\right\|_{2}\leq\left\|\bm{s}_{i}(t)\right\|_{2}\leq L_{3}\left\|\nabla_{i}F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t))\right\|_{2}.
  • (e)

    There is a positive constant δ𝛿\delta, such that

    ‖𝒔i​(t)−𝒔j​(t)‖2≤δ​min⁡(‖𝒔i​(t)‖2,‖𝒔j​(t)‖2),subscriptnormsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑡subscript𝒔𝑗𝑡2𝛿subscriptnormsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑡2subscriptnormsubscript𝒔𝑗𝑡2\|\bm{s}_{i}(t)-\bm{s}_{j}(t)\|_{2}\leq\delta\min\left(\|\bm{s}_{i}(t)\|_{2},\,\|\bm{s}_{j}(t)\|_{2}\right),

    where δ𝛿\delta is a convergence bound of ‖𝒔i​(t)−𝒔j​(t)‖2subscriptnormsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑡subscript𝒔𝑗𝑡2\|\bm{s}_{i}(t)-\bm{s}_{j}(t)\|_{2}.

Assumption 2(a) means that the loss functions take non-negative values. The smooth assumption given by Assumption 2(b) indicates how fast the gradient of Fi​(𝒙)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙F_{i}(\bm{x}) can change. Assumption 2(c) implies that 𝒔i​(t)subscript𝒔𝑖𝑡\bm{s}_{i}(t) must be in the same Cartesian quadrant as −∇Fi​(𝒗i​(t))∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t)). To avoid gradient exploding and ensure the convergence of model training, Assumption 2(d) is necessary to restrict the scale of gradients. Moreover, Assumption 2(e) means a bounded local dissimilarity and a divergence of the gradients. It is evident that Assumptions 2(d) and 2(e) reveal the data heterogeneity and distribution over edge nodes [4]. All the assumptions mentioned above characterize the key features of loss and risk functions of existing machine learning models, which have been widely used in the literature about the convergence analysis of machine learning models, even for non-convex models [19, 23, 24].

By virtue of Assumption 2, we obtain the following lemma on F¯​(𝒘)¯𝐹𝒘\bar{F}(\bm{w}):

Lemma 2.

For any 𝐰𝐰\bm{w} and 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\bm{w}_{i}, we have

∇F¯​(𝒘)=∑i=1I∇iFi​(∑j=1Iαj​𝒘j),∇¯𝐹𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript∇𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝒘𝑗\nabla\bar{F}\left(\bm{w}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{I}\nabla_{i}F_{i}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{I}\alpha_{j}\bm{w}_{j}\right), (15)

and

‖∇F¯​(𝒙)−∇F¯​(𝒚)‖2≤L1​‖𝒙−𝒚‖2,∀𝒙,𝒚∈𝒲.formulae-sequencesubscriptnorm∇¯𝐹𝒙∇¯𝐹𝒚2subscript𝐿1subscriptnorm𝒙𝒚2for-all𝒙𝒚𝒲\|\nabla\bar{F}(\bm{x})-\nabla\bar{F}(\bm{y})\|_{2}\leq L_{1}\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|_{2},\,\forall\bm{x},\,\bm{y}\in\mathcal{W}. (16)
Proof.

By definition, we have

∇iFi​(∑j=1Iαj​𝒘j)=αi​∇Fi​(𝒘).subscript∇𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝒘𝑗subscript𝛼𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\nabla_{i}F_{i}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{I}\alpha_{j}\bm{w}_{j}\right)=\alpha_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}). (17)

Summing up (17) for i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I} and inserting it into (14) yields (15). On the other hand, by Assumption 2(b), we get

‖∇F¯​(𝒙)−∇F¯​(𝒚)‖22superscriptsubscriptnorm∇¯𝐹𝒙∇¯𝐹𝒚22\displaystyle\|\nabla\bar{F}(\bm{x})-\nabla\bar{F}(\bm{y})\|_{2}^{2}
=‖∑i=1Iαi​∇Fi​(𝒙)−∑i=1Iαi​∇Fi​(𝒚)‖22absentsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒚22\displaystyle=\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})-\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{y})\right\|_{2}^{2} (18a)
≤∑i=1Iαi​‖∇Fi​(𝒙)−∇Fi​(𝒚)‖22absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒚22\displaystyle\leq\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{y})\right\|_{2}^{2}
≤L12​‖𝒙−𝒚‖22,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐿12superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒙𝒚22\displaystyle\leq L_{1}^{2}\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|_{2}^{2}, (18b)

where (18a) is due to (15) and the last inequality of (18b) is obtained by using ∑i=1Iαi=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝛼𝑖1\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}=1. ∎

Now, we can formalize a convergence bound on how rapid the decrease of global loss is.

Theorem 2.

With Assumption 2, there exists a learning rate η>0𝜂0\eta>0 such that F¯​(𝐰​(t+1))¯𝐹𝐰𝑡1\bar{F}\left(\bm{w}(t+1)\right) converges to a bound given by

F¯​(𝒘​(t+1))≤F¯​(𝒘​(0))−η​u​(η)​∑τ=0t‖𝒈​(τ)‖22⏟U​(Γ),¯𝐹𝒘𝑡1subscript⏟¯𝐹𝒘0𝜂𝑢𝜂superscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑡superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒈𝜏22𝑈Γ\bar{F}\left(\bm{w}(t+1)\right)\leq\underbrace{\bar{F}\left(\bm{w}(0)\right)-\eta u(\eta)\sum_{\tau=0}^{t}\left\|\bm{g}(\tau)\right\|_{2}^{2}}_{U(\Gamma)}, (19)

where 𝐠​(τ)≜[𝐬1T​(τ),𝐬2T​(τ),⋯,𝐬IT​(τ)]T,∀τ=0,⋯,tformulae-sequence≜𝐠𝜏superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐬1𝑇𝜏superscriptsubscript𝐬2𝑇𝜏⋯superscriptsubscript𝐬𝐼𝑇𝜏𝑇for-all𝜏0⋯𝑡\bm{g}(\tau)\triangleq\left[\bm{s}_{1}^{T}(\tau),\,\bm{s}_{2}^{T}(\tau),\,\cdots,\,\bm{s}_{I}^{T}(\tau)\right]^{T},\,\forall\tau=0,\,\cdots,\,t, represents a stacked global gradient of all nodes, and u​(η)𝑢𝜂u(\eta) is defined as

u​(η)≜IL3−δ​(I−1)L2−(I​(3+η)−1)​L12−(3​I−1)​η2​L1​Γ22.≜𝑢𝜂𝐼subscript𝐿3𝛿𝐼1subscript𝐿2𝐼3𝜂1subscript𝐿123𝐼1superscript𝜂2subscript𝐿1superscriptΓ22u(\eta)\triangleq\dfrac{I}{L_{3}}-\dfrac{\delta(I-1)}{L_{2}}-\dfrac{\left(I(3+\eta)-1\right)L_{1}}{2}-\dfrac{(3I-1)\eta^{2}L_{1}\Gamma^{2}}{2}.
Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

Theorem 2 shows that the learning rate η𝜂\eta and the number of transmission delay ΓΓ\Gamma are vital factors to determine the upper bound of divergence in our distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing. Moreover, we can make some exciting corollaries from Theorem 2.

Corollary 1.

Theorem 2 infers that

limt→+∞𝒘i​(t)=limt→+∞𝒘i​(τj,i​(t)),∀i,j∈ℐ,formulae-sequencesubscript→𝑡subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡subscript→𝑡subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡for-all𝑖𝑗ℐ\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\bm{w}_{i}(t)=\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\bm{w}_{i}(\tau_{j,\,i}(t)),\,\forall i,\,j\in\mathcal{I}, (20)

and

limt→+∞𝒘​(t)=limt→+∞𝒗i​(t),∀i∈ℐ.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝑡𝒘𝑡subscript→𝑡subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡for-all𝑖ℐ\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\bm{w}(t)=\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\bm{v}_{i}(t),\ \forall i\in\mathcal{I}. (21)
Proof.

See Appendix C. ∎

In essence, (20) implies that each model can converge independently; (21) shows that we can obtain an aggregated model at each node, which converges to the same global model. The reason behind these observations is that the sharing parameter 𝒘i|shsubscript𝒘conditional𝑖sh\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}} can restrict the severity of local deviations if they increase with the number of iterations.

Corollary 2.

Given Assumption 2, there exists a learning rate η>0𝜂0\eta>0, such that F¯​(𝐰​(t+1))¯𝐹𝐰𝑡1\bar{F}\left(\bm{w}(t+1)\right) converges to a fixed value. If η2<δ≪η<1superscript𝜂2𝛿much-less-than𝜂1\eta^{2}<\delta\ll\eta<1, then we obtain

δ<η⪅min⁡(𝒪​(2L1​L3−3​I−1I),δ).𝛿𝜂less-than-or-approximately-equals𝒪2subscript𝐿1subscript𝐿33𝐼1𝐼𝛿\delta<\eta\lessapprox\min\left(\mathcal{O}\left(\dfrac{2}{L_{1}L_{3}}-\dfrac{3I-1}{I}\right),\,\sqrt{\delta}\right). (22)
Proof.

Assume that η2<δ≪η<1superscript𝜂2𝛿much-less-than𝜂1\eta^{2}<\delta\ll\eta<1, then the term u​(η)𝑢𝜂u(\eta) defined in (19) can be approximated as u​(η)≈I/L3−I​η​L1/2−(3​I−1)​L1/2𝑢𝜂𝐼subscript𝐿3𝐼𝜂subscript𝐿123𝐼1subscript𝐿12u(\eta)\thickapprox{I}/{L_{3}}-{I\eta L_{1}}/{2}-{(3I-1)L_{1}}/{2}. Since the constraint u​(η)>0𝑢𝜂0u(\eta)>0 is satisfied naturally, we attain

0<η⪅𝒪​(2L1​L3−3​I−1I).0𝜂less-than-or-approximately-equals𝒪2subscript𝐿1subscript𝐿33𝐼1𝐼0<\eta\lessapprox\mathcal{O}\left(\dfrac{2}{L_{1}L_{3}}-\dfrac{3I-1}{I}\right). (23)

In case of η2<δ≪η<1superscript𝜂2𝛿much-less-than𝜂1\eta^{2}<\delta\ll\eta<1 and (23), we can readily obtain (22). ∎

Corollary 2 states that the learning rate η𝜂\eta is naturally in a reasonable range to guarantee convergence. The convergence rate is prolonged if η𝜂\eta is small. On the other hand, if η𝜂\eta is large, the term involving η2superscript𝜂2\eta^{2} in the parenthesis of (19) cannot be ignored anymore, yielding stochastic fluctuations due to different transmission delays among nodes. In the next section, we aim to minimize the maximum of transmission delays.

V Wireless Resource Allocation

In this section, we develop efficient communications for parameter sharing in highly distributed networks. In particular, it is observed from Theorem 2 that minimizing the upper bound is essential to obtain a good convergence in each iteration period. Therefore, it is natural to minimize the convergence bound U​(Γ)𝑈ΓU(\Gamma) defined in (19) concerning the aggregated duration ΓΓ\Gamma, where Γ≜ΓW+ΓT≜ΓsubscriptΓ𝑊subscriptΓ𝑇\Gamma\triangleq\Gamma_{W}+\Gamma_{T} includes the number of waiting duration ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W} and the maximal transmission duration ΓTsubscriptΓ𝑇\Gamma_{T}. Specifically, ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W} is from the reserved duration for unscheduled nodes [25], and ΓTsubscriptΓ𝑇\Gamma_{T} is associated with the transmission delay [26]. However, as ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W} varies due to the randomness of channels, it is hard to express ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W} explicitly and provide a corresponding optimization. Therefore, we design a scheduling strategy and a bandwidth allocation algorithm for efficient wireless resource allocation.

Like [5, 27], we consider a typical wireless network where all user nodes are uniformly distributed. The network coverage area is tessellated into Voronoi cells using the nearest-neighbor association criteria, i.e., each node is associated with its nearest base station (BS) [28]. We assume that the locations of user nodes follow a homogeneous Poisson point process (PPP) with a pre-defined spatial density. A fixed amount of spectrum resource is divided into multiple spectrum bands for efficient spectral utilization. Each node with a single antenna broadcasts the same parameters to others through its allocated spectrum band. A block-fading propagation model is adopted, where the channels between any two nodes are independently and identically distributed (i.i.d.) and keep quasi-static in the parameter transmission period. In addition, the propagation channels are supposed to be narrow-band (which is true in IoT applications), and large-scale path loss and small-scale fading are accounted for as usual.

V-A Scheduling Strategy

In this subsection, we start to analyze the waiting duration ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W} during transmission. Using Slivnyak’s theorem, it is sufficient to evaluate the communication quality through the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) at a typical node [6]. For the parameter transmission from node i𝑖i to j𝑗j, the SINR at node j𝑗j can be expressed as [29]

SINRj,i=P​hj,i​dj,i−α∑x∈ΦjP​hj,x​dj,x−α+σ2,subscriptSINR𝑗𝑖𝑃subscriptℎ𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑗𝑖𝛼subscript𝑥subscriptΦ𝑗𝑃subscriptℎ𝑗𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑗𝑥𝛼superscript𝜎2{\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}=\dfrac{Ph_{j,\,i}d_{j,\,i}^{-\alpha}}{\sum_{x\in\Phi_{j}}Ph_{j,\,x}d_{j,\,x}^{-\alpha}+\sigma^{2}}, (24)

where all nodes are assumed to have the same transmit power P𝑃P, the symbol hj,i∼exp⁡(1)similar-tosubscriptℎ𝑗𝑖1h_{j,\,i}\sim\exp(1) reflects a small-scale fading with unity power (i.e., 𝔼​{|hj,i|2}=1𝔼superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑗𝑖21\mathbb{E}\{|h_{j,\,i}|^{2}\}=1), dj,isubscript𝑑𝑗𝑖d_{j,\,i} denotes a Euclidean distance between nodes i𝑖i and j𝑗j, α𝛼\alpha is a path loss exponent, the set ΦjsubscriptΦ𝑗\Phi_{j} stands for out-of-cell nodes interfering with node j𝑗j, and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} denotes the variance of additive white Gaussian noises.

Due to the limited wireless resources of low-cost IoT nodes, they are divided into distinct groups, each associated with a particular learning task. Accordingly, each node exchanges its learning parameters within the group per se. To obtain good communication qualities in the transmission period, the SINR must exceed a threshold γ𝛾\gamma, i.e., SINRj,i>γsubscriptSINR𝑗𝑖𝛾{\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}>\gamma at node j𝑗j [30]; otherwise, a transmission outage occurs. Meanwhile, we define two different node sets as

𝒴i​(t+1)subscript𝒴𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1) ≜{j|𝕀​(SINRj,i>γ)=1,∀j∈ℐ∖i},≜absentconditional-set𝑗formulae-sequence𝕀subscriptSINR𝑗𝑖𝛾1for-all𝑗ℐ𝑖\displaystyle\triangleq\left\{j\left|\mathbb{I}\left({\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}>\gamma\right)=1,\,\forall j\in\mathcal{I}\setminus i\right.\right\}, (25a)
ℐ¯¯ℐ\displaystyle\bar{\mathcal{I}} ≜{i∈ℐ|𝕀​(𝒴i​(t+1)≠∅)=1},∀i∈ℐ,formulae-sequence≜absentconditional-set𝑖ℐ𝕀subscript𝒴𝑖𝑡11for-all𝑖ℐ\displaystyle\triangleq\{i\in\mathcal{I}|\mathbb{I}\left(\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)\neq\emptyset\right)=1\},\,\forall i\in\mathcal{I}, (25b)

where 𝒴i​(t+1)subscript𝒴𝑖𝑡1\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1) represents the set of nodes that receive parameters from node i𝑖i, and ℐ¯¯ℐ\bar{\mathcal{I}} is the set of nodes that have been scheduled in this wireless network. More specifically, 𝕀​(SINRj,i>γ)𝕀subscriptSINR𝑗𝑖𝛾\mathbb{I}\left({\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}>\gamma\right) denotes a scheduled state whether node i𝑖i is scheduled by node j𝑗j while 𝕀​(𝒴i​(t+1)≠∅)𝕀subscript𝒴𝑖𝑡1\mathbb{I}\left(\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)\neq\emptyset\right) represents a scheduled state whether node i𝑖i has been scheduled at least once in this wireless network.

In theory, it is challenging to formulate an optimization problem about the SINR threshold γ𝛾\gamma due to the varying ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W}. In practice, as the value of γ𝛾\gamma depends on the expectation of wireless channels and SINR, it can be optimized numerically by a grid search [20]. To reduce the computational complexity, we consider two extreme cases for an appropriate γ𝛾\gamma. If the wireless network operates at a relatively high SINR, i.e., γ≫0much-greater-than𝛾0\gamma\gg 0 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B}, the number of scheduled nodes decreases monotonically, as implied by (25). Hence, the number of waiting duration ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W} increases rapidly, yielding a large ΓΓ\Gamma. Clearly, a significant ΓΓ\Gamma would deteriorate the convergence process and require more training iterations. In contrast, if the wireless network operates at low SINR, i.e., γ≪0​dBmuch-less-than𝛾0dB\gamma\ll 0\,{\rm dB}, the number of scheduled nodes increases rapidly. However, the additional nodes exacerbate the competition for communication resources, resulting in a considerable transmission duration ΓTsubscriptΓ𝑇\Gamma_{T}, which also deteriorates the learning process. Consequently, we can conclude that an appropriate value γ𝛾\gamma benefits making a balance between the waiting duration ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W} and the maximal transmission duration ΓTsubscriptΓ𝑇\Gamma_{T} to minimize the total aggregated duration ΓΓ\Gamma. Moreover, it is widely known that SINR and γ𝛾\gamma values depend heavily on the interference and channel fading among user nodes [31]. As the waiting duration ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W} reserved for unscheduled nodes is fixed if the scheduling is determined by (25), the maximal transmission duration ΓTsubscriptΓ𝑇\Gamma_{T} can be employed to replace the optimal variable ΓΓ\Gamma for efficient resource allocation.

V-B Bandwidth Allocation

As illustrated in Fig. 3, Γj,isubscriptΓ𝑗𝑖\Gamma_{j,\,i} denotes the transmission duration in each parameter transmission period. Then, ΓTsubscriptΓ𝑇\Gamma_{T} can be computed as

ΓT=maxi∈ℐ¯⁡maxj∈𝒴i​(t+1)⁡Γj,i.subscriptΓ𝑇subscript𝑖¯ℐsubscript𝑗subscript𝒴𝑖𝑡1subscriptΓ𝑗𝑖\Gamma_{T}=\max_{i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}}\max_{j\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)}\Gamma_{j,\,i}. (26)

When the amount of transmission parameters is large, the parameter sparsity is necessarily accounted for to reduce transmission burden on wireless networks333It is well-known that when training a complex deep neural network model using stochastic gradient descent methods, model updates can be highly sparse. Indeed, it has been shown that when training some of the popular large-scale architectures, such as ResNet [32] or VGG [33], sparse levels of [0.001,0.01]0.0010.01\left[0.001,0.01\right] provides a significant reduction in the communication load with almost no loss in their generalization performance [34].. In practice, each node only transmits non-zero parameters and their locations [31], such that Γj,isubscriptΓ𝑗𝑖\Gamma_{j,\,i} can be computed as

Γj,i=qi​ST​Bi​log2⁡(1+SINRj,i),∀j∈𝒴i​(t+1),i∈ℐ¯,formulae-sequencesubscriptΓ𝑗𝑖subscript𝑞𝑖𝑆𝑇subscript𝐵𝑖subscript21subscriptSINR𝑗𝑖formulae-sequencefor-all𝑗subscript𝒴𝑖𝑡1𝑖¯ℐ\Gamma_{j,\,i}=\dfrac{q_{i}S}{TB_{i}\log_{2}\left(1+{\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}\right)},\,\forall j\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1),\,i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}, (27)

where qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} is a sparsity ratio, S𝑆S is the total amount of the quantized parameter bits, T𝑇T is an average training latency for each iteration, and Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} is an optimal bandwidth for node i𝑖i. In this paper, we set qi=1subscript𝑞𝑖1q_{i}=1 since a weight decay 1/2​‖𝒘i‖2212superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑖221/2\|\bm{w}_{i}\|_{2}^{2} is considered for regularization terms.

To determine the transmission duration Γj,isubscriptΓ𝑗𝑖\Gamma_{j,\,i} shown in (27), we first assume that each node has a deterministic training latency T𝑇T at each node444In this paper, we assume that each node has the similar computation capability, and all data samples at each node have the same data size. Therefore, we set the average training latency T𝑇T as a constant for all nodes. A similar assumption is widely adopted in the literature, like [35]., and then estimate T𝑇T in GPU modes. Unlike the serial mode of the CPU, the GPU processes datasets in parallel. When the training batch size is small, GPU can directly process the dataset simultaneously, yielding a constant training latency T0subscript𝑇0T_{0}. On the contrary, the training latency T𝑇T grows linearly if the training batch size exceeds a threshold Dthsubscript𝐷thD_{\rm th}. With this consideration, Assumption 111 in [24] describes a computation model on the local training latency T𝑇T and the training batch size. It reveals that the local training latency grows linearly when the training batch size exceeds a threshold Dthsubscript𝐷thD_{\rm th}. Moreover, one training duration per iteration is usually as long as several seconds. It is because of the high computational complexity and the limited computation resource of nodes for processing large training sampling per iteration. However, communication time slots are relatively short [31]. Therefore, the transmission duration Γj,isubscriptΓ𝑗𝑖\Gamma_{j,\,i} computed by (27) is small. In light of (26) and (27), we formulate an achievable transmission rate maximization problem as

𝒫​3:max{Bi}i∈ℐ¯⁡mini∈ℐ¯,j∈𝒴i​(t+1):𝒫3subscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑖¯ℐsubscript𝑖¯ℐ𝑗subscript𝒴𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle\mathcal{P}{3}:\max_{\left\{B_{i}\right\}_{i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}}}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}},\\ j\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)\end{subarray}}\, Bi​log2⁡(1+SINRj,i)subscript𝐵𝑖subscript21subscriptSINR𝑗𝑖\displaystyle B_{i}\log_{2}\left(1+{\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}\right) (28a)
s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle{\rm s.t.}\quad ∑i∈ℐ¯Bi≤B,subscript𝑖¯ℐsubscript𝐵𝑖𝐵\displaystyle\sum_{i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}}B_{i}\leq B, (28b)
Bi≥0,∀i∈ℐ¯,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐵𝑖0for-all𝑖¯ℐ\displaystyle B_{i}\geq 0,\,\forall i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}, (28c)

where B𝐵B is the total bandwidth. Clearly, 𝒫​3𝒫3\mathcal{P}{3} is indeed a transmission delay minimization problem, which is convex and can be easily solved by the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions [36, p. 243]. Therefore, the optimal bandwidth allocation can be formalized in the following proposition.

With Proposition 1, our decentralized FL model can be readily deployed in wireless distributed networks. Accordingly, we formalize a distributed algorithm in Algorithm 1, where three types of states control the learning process. In particular, when the sharing parameter is transmitted from node j𝑗j to i𝑖i, the received state Ji,jsubscript𝐽𝑖𝑗J_{i,\,j} denotes whether node i𝑖i has received the parameter from node j𝑗j or not. The scheduled state Qi,jsubscript𝑄𝑖𝑗Q_{i,\,j} indicates whether node i𝑖i schedules node j𝑗j or not, while the state Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i} reflects whether other nodes schedule node i𝑖i or not, i.e., 𝒴i​(t+1)≠∅subscript𝒴𝑖𝑡1\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)\neq\emptyset, which is used to update the node set ℐ¯¯ℐ\bar{\mathcal{I}} defined by (25b).

Proposition 1 (Bandwidth allocation).

Given the node set ℐ¯¯ℐ\bar{\mathcal{I}} in the (t+1)thsuperscript𝑡1th(t+1)^{\rm th} parameter transmission period, the optimal bandwidth allocation is given by

Bi∗={BRi​(∑i′∈ℐ¯1Ri′)−1,if​i∈ℐ¯;0,otherwise,superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖cases𝐵subscript𝑅𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑖′¯ℐ1subscript𝑅superscript𝑖′1if𝑖¯ℐ0otherwiseB_{i}^{*}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{rl}\dfrac{B}{R_{i}}\left(\sum\limits_{i^{\prime}\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}}\dfrac{1}{R_{i^{\prime}}}\right)^{-1},&\text{if}~{}i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}};\\ 0,&\text{otherwise},\end{array}\right. (29)

where Ri=minj∈𝒴i​(t+1)⁡log2⁡(1+SINRj,i),i∈ℐ¯formulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝒴𝑖𝑡1subscript21subscriptSINR𝑗𝑖𝑖¯ℐR_{i}=\min_{j\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)}\log_{2}\left(1+{\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}\right),\,i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}, is an average uplink data rate during the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\rm th} transmission period.

For better clarity of Algorithm 1, Fig. 4a shows the four built-in modules in each iteration period: a learning module, a parameter reception module, a bandwidth allocation module, and a parameter transmission module. In particular, Module 1, i.e., Line 333 of Algorithm 1, states that the learning module includes local parameter aggregation and parameter updates. On the other hand, Figs. 4b-4d plots the flowcharts of Modules 2-4, respectively. In the parameter reception module, Fig. 4b shows that the current node receives the SINR, data rate, three states above, and learning parameters from other nodes, which are realized in lines 4-9 of Algorithm 1. Lines 101010-151515 realize the bandwidth allocation module shown in Fig. 4c. Among them, line 10 means that node i𝑖i cannot transmit the current learning parameter to other nodes until it has finished all transmissions in the last parameter transmission process; line 11 sets a scheduling strategy for scheduled nodes. Each aggregated period has a separate iteration index tSsubscript𝑡St_{\rm S} that records the moment of the parameter transmission. Line 12 feeds main states back to other nodes, and lines 13-14 compute the data rate and optimal bandwidth for the next iteration period. Lines 16-21 realize the parameter transmission module shown in Fig. 4d, including two main steps: computing the SINR in line 17 and transmitting the learning parameters in lines 18-20.

VI Simulation Results and Discussions

In this section, we present and discuss Monte-Carlo simulation results to exhibit the learning performance of the developed algorithm in terms of convergence analysis, node scheduling, and bandwidth allocation. In the pertaining simulation experiments, the workstation is equipped with an Intel(X) E555-262026202620 CPU and four NVIDIA GeForce RTX 309030903090 graphic cards. We build a TensorFlow (TF) simulation environment and then train our proposed model by the deterministic gradient descent algorithm.

VI-A Convergence Analysis

This subsection evaluates the learning performance of Algorithm 1 without bandwidth allocation. For comparison purposes, we perform experiments on two typical datasets using CNN as follows: the MNIST [37] and CIFAR datasets [38]. In particular, the MNIST dataset contains 70,0007000070,000 28×28282828\times 28 grayscale images of handwritten digits (more specifically, 60,0006000060,000 for training and 10,0001000010,000 for testing). The CIFAR dataset contains 60,0006000060,000 32×32323232\times 32 color images (more specifically, 50,0005000050,000 for training and 10,0001000010,000 for testing). The images in each dataset are divided into 101010 classes with an equal number of images per class. The CNN has 999 layers with the following structure: 5×5×3255325\times 5\times 32 Convolutional →→\rightarrow 2×2222\times 2 MaxPool →→\rightarrow Local Response Normalization →→\rightarrow 5×5×3255325\times 5\times 32 Convolutional →→\rightarrow Local Response Normalization →→\rightarrow 2×2222\times 2 MaxPool →→\rightarrow z×256𝑧256z\times 256 Fully connected →→\rightarrow 256×1025610256\times 10 Fully connected →→\rightarrow Softmax, where z=1568𝑧1568z=1568 for the MNIST and z=2048𝑧2048z=2048 for the CIFAR [4]. In the simulation experiments, we consider five typical schemes: the centralized FL averaging model (FedAv for short) [1]; adaptive FL model (AdaFL for short) [4]; the FedAv-partial model (FedAP for short), in which the parameter server selects partial nodes for the global updating to avoid the impacts of stragglers [39]; the semi-asynchronous FL model (FedSA for short), where the parameter server aggregates a certain number of local models by their arrival order in each round [39]; and Algorithm 1 without bandwidth allocation, i.e., the pseudo-code in the box of Algorithm 1 is excluded (Alg. 111 w/o BWA for short). Note that Algorithm 1 is reduced for a fair comparison.

Figure 5 depicts the learning performance versus the number of iterations, where the number of nodes is set to I=5,10,15𝐼51015I=5,10,15. On the one hand, we observe from Fig. 5a that the training losses of Algorithm 1 are lower than those for comparison. The reason behind this observation is that our decentralized FL model of 𝒫​1𝒫1\mathcal{P}1 has a less-nonconvex objective function than the centralized FL averaging model [1] and adaptive FL model [4]. Also, it is observed that when the number of nodes increases from 555 to 101010 till 151515, the training loss of Algorithm 1 converges to a lower and lower value. This observation is because the normalized duality gap decreases as the number of nodes increases. Thus, our proposed model becomes more and more convex when a large dataset is distributed over each node uniformly. Consequently, this makes the learning process faster to obtain an optimal solution. On the other hand, Fig. 5b also shows that the testing accuracies of Algorithm 1 outperform the benchmark algorithms under study, and more nodes involved lead to higher testing accuracy, as expected. As far as the CIFAR dataset is concerned, Figs. 5c-5d show similar performance to Figs. 5a-5b, respectively. Accordingly, in the rest of this section, we only report the results regarding the MNIST dataset to reduce redundancy.

Figure 6 illustrates the learning performance versus the number of iterations, where the transmission delays are set to Γ=5,10,15Γ51015\Gamma=5,10,15. In particular, the centralized FL averaging model is independent of ΓΓ\Gamma as the transmission delays and aggregated durations do not influence learning performance. On the one hand, Fig. 6a shows that the training losses of Algorithm 1 are lower than the benchmark algorithms under study. Moreover, as ΓΓ\Gamma decreases from 151515 to 101010 till 555, the training loss of Algorithm 1 becomes smaller and smaller. The reason behind these observations is that, given a smaller transmission delay ΓΓ\Gamma, our decentralized FL model can faster aggregate sharing parameters from other nodes, thus leading to a lower upper bound and a faster convergence rate, by Theorem 2. Instead, when ΓΓ\Gamma becomes large, the proposed model can only obtain sharing parameters with a large delay, slightly slowing down the convergence. On the other hand, Fig. 6b shows that the testing accuracy of Algorithm 1 outperforms the benchmark algorithms under study, regardless of ΓΓ\Gamma.

VI-B Effect of Node Scheduling and Bandwidth Allocation

This subsection illustrates the effectiveness of node scheduling and bandwidth allocation. In the pertaining simulation experiments, we adopt similar wireless parameters as those reported in [27], and their default values are summarized in Table III unless specified otherwise. Apart from the conventional centralized FL averaging model (FedAv for short) [1] and Algorithm 1 with optimal resource allocation (Alg. 111 for short), we also consider two other benchmark ones: the distributed FL algorithms with uniform bandwidth allocation (Distributed+Uniform for short) or random bandwidth allocation (Distributed+Random for short).

Figure 7 illustrates the effect of node scheduling by adjusting different SINR thresholds (say, γ𝛾\gamma) in Algorithm 1. On the one hand, Fig. 7a shows that, given γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B}, the training loss of Algorithm 1 is lower than those of γ=−15𝛾15\gamma=-15 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B} and γ=15𝛾15\gamma=15 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B}, and perform a bit smaller than the centralized algorithm. These observations are because, given a low SINR threshold γ𝛾\gamma, many nodes are scheduled, and the channels with poor SINR cannot obtain sufficient bandwidth. As a result, the transmission delay and aggregated duration become large, thus leading to a low convergence rate. Meanwhile, many nodes are not scheduled given a high SINR threshold γ𝛾\gamma. Hence, the waiting duration ΓWsubscriptΓ𝑊\Gamma_{W} reserved for unscheduled nodes increases, resulting in poor learning performance. On the other hand, Fig. 7b shows that the testing accuracy with γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B} is higher than those of γ=−15𝛾15\gamma=-15 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B} and γ=15𝛾15\gamma=15 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B}. Therefore, adopting a medium SINR threshold is critical to achieving good convergence performance of our decentralized FL model.

Figure 8 compares Algorithm 1 with state-of-the-art algorithms in resource-limited settings, including FedSA and FedAP, and Algorithm 1 with different bandwidth allocation mechanisms, including uniform and random allocation mechanisms. On the one hand, Fig. 8a shows that Algorithm 1 and the centralized algorithm achieve similar training losses, both lower than the benchmark ones under study. The reason stems from the fact that Algorithm 1 can allocate bandwidth optimally such that the transmission delay and aggregated duration can also be minimized. Theorem 2 implies that a low aggregated duration leads to a low convergence bound and accelerates the training process. However, the random and uniform bandwidth allocations are not optimal, thus resulting in a longer transmission delay and aggregated duration than Algorithm 1. Moreover, it is observed that Algorithm 1 and FedSA have a lower learning loss than FedAP. The reason is that the FedAP algorithm only schedules partial nodes for the global aggregation and has data deficiency due to the communication stragglers. Algorithm 1 also has a lower learning loss than FedSA due to its sharing parameters and less non-convexity. On the other hand, Fig. 8b shows that the testing accuracy of Algorithm 1 is also higher than the others. Therefore, we can infer that the decentralized FL model with optimal bandwidth allocation enables efficient learning even in resource-limited wireless networks.

VII Concluding Remarks

This paper has developed a decentralized FL model with less non-convex summation functions to adapt to distributed network architecture, especially for resource-constrained large-scale IoT networks. With the increasing number of nodes, this paper has derived a duality gap to control the non-convexity of our proposed decentralized FL model and improve the learning performance. To realize efficient learning, this paper has also proposed a gradient descent algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing and a convergence analysis to mitigate the influence of stochastic transmission delays. Moreover, we established the relationship between the convergence bound and the transmission delay for efficient communication and excellent learning performance in resource-constrained IoT networks. It improved the learning performance by minimizing the transmission delay. In future works, we will incorporate the data distribution divergence over nodes and design a new gradient descent to deal with insufficient data samples.

Summing up among the 1st,⋯,tthsuperscript1st⋯superscript𝑡th1^{\rm st},\,\cdots,\,t^{\rm th} iterations, we get

−(3​I−1)​η2​L1​Γ22)∑τ=0t∥𝒈(τ)∥22.\displaystyle\quad{}-\,\left.\dfrac{(3I-1)\eta^{2}L_{1}\Gamma^{2}}{2}\right)\sum_{\tau=0}^{t}\left\|\bm{g}(\tau)\right\|_{2}^{2}.

This completes the proof.

Appendix C Proof of Corollary 1

From Assumption 2(a), we have F¯​(𝒘​(t+1))≥0¯𝐹𝒘𝑡10\bar{F}(\bm{w}(t+1))\geq 0, and then (19) can be rewritten as

∑τ=0t‖𝒈​(τ)‖22≤1η​u​(η)​F¯​(𝒘​(0))<+∞,t≥0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑡superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒈𝜏221𝜂𝑢𝜂¯𝐹𝒘0𝑡0\sum_{\tau=0}^{t}\left\|\bm{g}(\tau)\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq\dfrac{1}{\eta u(\eta)}\bar{F}\left(\bm{w}(0)\right)<+\infty,\,t\geq 0 (C.1)

which implies that

limt→+∞𝒈​(t)=0,limt→+∞𝒔i​(t)=0,∀i∈ℐ.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝑡𝒈𝑡0formulae-sequencesubscript→𝑡subscript𝒔𝑖𝑡0for-all𝑖ℐ\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\bm{g}(t)=0,\,\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\bm{s}_{i}(t)=0,\,\forall i\in\mathcal{I}. (C.2)

By using (13), we deduce that

𝒘i​(t)=𝒘i​(τj,i​(t))+η​∑τ=τj,i​(t)t−1𝒔i​(τ),∀i∈ℐ.formulae-sequencesubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡𝜂superscriptsubscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡𝑡1subscript𝒔𝑖𝜏for-all𝑖ℐ\bm{w}_{i}(t)=\bm{w}_{i}(\tau_{j,\,i}(t))+\eta\sum_{\tau=\tau_{j,\,i}(t)}^{t-1}\bm{s}_{i}(\tau),\,\forall i\in\mathcal{I}. (C.3)

As t−τj,i​(t)≤Γ𝑡subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡Γt-\tau_{j,\,i}(t)\leq\Gamma, we obtain limt→+∞τj,i​(t)=t→+∞subscript→𝑡subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡𝑡→\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\tau_{j,\,i}(t)=t\rightarrow+\infty, and

limt→+∞‖∑τ=τj,i​(t)t−1𝒔i​(τ)‖2≤limt→+∞∑τ=τj,i​(t)t−1‖𝒔i​(τ)‖2subscript→𝑡subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡𝑡1subscript𝒔𝑖𝜏2subscript→𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡𝑡1subscriptnormsubscript𝒔𝑖𝜏2\displaystyle\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\left\|\sum_{\tau=\tau_{j,\,i}(t)}^{t-1}\bm{s}_{i}(\tau)\right\|_{2}\leq\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\sum_{\tau=\tau_{j,\,i}(t)}^{t-1}\left\|\bm{s}_{i}(\tau)\right\|_{2}
≤Γ​limt→+∞‖𝒔i​(t)‖2=0,∀i∈ℐ,formulae-sequenceabsentΓsubscript→𝑡subscriptnormsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑡20for-all𝑖ℐ\displaystyle\leq\Gamma\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\left\|\bm{s}_{i}(t)\right\|_{2}=0,\,\forall i\in\mathcal{I}, (C.4)

where (C.4) is obtained by (C.2). Using (C.4), we have

limt→+∞‖𝒘i​(t)−𝒘i​(τj,i​(t))‖2=0,subscript→𝑡subscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑗𝑖𝑡20\displaystyle\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\|\bm{w}_{i}(t)-\bm{w}_{i}(\tau_{j,\,i}(t))\|_{2}=0,

Moreover, we have

‖𝒘​(t)−𝒗i​(t)‖2=‖𝒘​(t)−∑j∈ℐαj​𝒘j​(τi,j​(t))‖2subscriptnorm𝒘𝑡subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡2subscriptnorm𝒘𝑡subscript𝑗ℐsubscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝒘𝑗subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡2\displaystyle\|\bm{w}(t)-\bm{v}_{i}(t)\|_{2}=\left\|\bm{w}(t)-\sum_{j\in\mathcal{I}}\alpha_{j}\bm{w}_{j}\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right)\right\|_{2}
=η​‖∑j∈ℐαj​∑τ=τi,j​(t)t−1𝒔j​(τ)‖2,∀i∈ℐ.formulae-sequenceabsent𝜂subscriptnormsubscript𝑗ℐsubscript𝛼𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜏subscript𝜏𝑖𝑗𝑡𝑡1subscript𝒔𝑗𝜏2for-all𝑖ℐ\displaystyle=\eta\left\|\sum_{j\in\mathcal{I}}\alpha_{j}\sum_{\tau=\tau_{i,\,j}(t)}^{t-1}\bm{s}_{j}(\tau)\right\|_{2},\,\forall i\in\mathcal{I}. (C.6)

Combining (C.4) and (C.6) concludes that

limt→+∞‖𝒘​(t)−𝒗i​(t)‖2=0,limt→+∞𝒘​(t)=limt→+∞𝒗i​(t).formulae-sequencesubscript→𝑡subscriptnorm𝒘𝑡subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡20subscript→𝑡𝒘𝑡subscript→𝑡subscript𝒗𝑖𝑡\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\|\bm{w}(t)-\bm{v}_{i}(t)\|_{2}=0,\,\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\bm{w}(t)=\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow+\infty}\bm{v}_{i}(t).
